title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: National Institutes Health (NIH) major source federal funding biomedical research United States. Analysis past current NIH funding can illustrate funding trends identify productive research topics, analyses conducted ad hoc institutes provide small glimpse available data. NIH provides free access funding data via NIH EXPORTER, tools developed enable analysis data. developed nihexporter R package, provides access NIH EXPORTER data. used package develop several analysis vignettes show funding trends across NIH institutes 15 years highlight differences institutes change funding profiles. Investigators institutions can use package perform self-studies NIH funding. nihexporter R package can installed via github.

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: National Institutes Health (NIH) major source federal funds biomedical research United States. NIH budget approved Congress year, fiscal year 2014, total NIH budget 30.3 billion dollars (REF). NIH divided 25 institutes, focus mission. example, National Cancer Institue (NCI) focuses malignant diseases; National Institute Allergy Immune Disease focuses immune system transmissible diseasei; National Institute General Medical Sciences focuses basic research without specific disease focus. institute negotiates NIH director (currently Francis Collins, MD, PhD) yearly budget, budget institutes ranging millions several billion dollars. NIH provides funds competitive grants written internal external investigators, funds associated grants can divided ‘direct’ ‘indirect’ costs. Direct costs funds given investigator (group investigators) conduct proposed research. funds buy supplies experiments pay salaries people work. contrast, indirect costs funds paid institutions associated investigators, used “keep lights ”: pay infrastructure costs. However, “indirect cost recovery” (ICR) rate institution, fraction award institute receives, congressionally mandated, wide range ICR rates. highest ICR rates close 100%, meaning every dollar investigator receives, institutions receive equal amount. NIH funding investment strategy: institutes invest money specific research areas, hoping future returns form publications, patents skilled trainees. investment strategy, periodic review can help rebalance portfolio order maximize returns. Analysis NIH funding data performed internally NIH, contracted third-parties. Several analyses highlighted funding trends suggested metrics gauge ‘return’ NIH ‘investment’. example, “productivity” can examined function number publications produced grants per dollar “direct costs”.

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: downloaded NIH funding data NIH EXPORTER website comma-separated value (CSV) format parsed data R data files contain specific information: projects information projects fiscal year, keyed project.num org_info information project organizations project_orgs links applications organizations project_pis links PI information project publinks table links PubMed IDs project.num publications links project IDs PubMed IDs patents links patent IDs project IDs See documentation R package information table. package also several precomputed variables tables enable quick easy exploratory analysis: nih_institutes: Two-letter format 27 NIH institutes project_io: table contains pre-computed values overall project cost (project_cost), well number publications (n_pubs) patents (n_patents) associated project. NIH EXPORTER provides access total costs grant fiscal year, comprising direct indirect costs. developed several analyses using dplyr, ggplot2 knitr packages RStudio environment.

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: Let’s look costs grants time institutes: Project spending NIGMS, NCI NIAID
code: library(nihexporter) library(tidyverse) library(scales) select_inst <- c('GM', 'AI', 'CA') cost.over.time <- projects |>   select(institute, fy_cost, fiscal_year) |>   filter(institute %in% select_inst) |>   group_by(fiscal_year, institute) |>   summarize(yearly_cost = sum(fy_cost, na.rm = TRUE))  cost.over.time |>   ggplot(aes(x = factor(fiscal_year),               y = yearly_cost / 1e9,              group = institute, color = institute)) +   geom_line() + geom_point() +   theme_bw() +   theme(legend.position = 'bottom') +   xlab('Fiscal year') +   ylab('Project costs (dollars in billions)')

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: Let’s look money going. example illustrates linking project, org_info project_orgs tables. R01 grant dollars awarded specific institutions can also identify movers--shakers institution.
code: institution_funding <- projects |>   filter(activity == 'R01') |>   group_by(org_name, org_duns, fiscal_year) |>   summarise(total_dollars = sum(fy_cost, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   arrange(desc(total_dollars))  institution_funding |>   select(fiscal_year, org_name, org_duns, total_dollars) |>   filter(!is.na(org_duns)) |>   mutate(total_award_millions = total_dollars / 1e6) |>   select(-total_dollars) |>   head(10) |>    knitr::kable(caption='R01 grant dollars awarded to specific institutions',                col.names=c('Fiscal year', 'Org.',                            'DUNS', 'Dollars (millions)'))

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: One can also examine dollars accrued specific PIs. possible assign dollars directly PI, grants multiple investigators. Rather, total costs given PI associated grants NIH EXPORTER. identify PIs largest dollar amounts accrued R01 grants. R01 grant dollars associated specific PIs
code: dollars_per_pi <- projects |>   filter(activity == 'R01') |>   left_join(project_io, by = 'project_num') |>   left_join(project_pis, by = 'project_num') |>   filter(!is.na(pi_id)) |>   select(project_num, pi_id, total_cost) |>    unique() |>   group_by(pi_id) |>   summarise(pi_dollars = sum(total_cost) / 1e6) |>   arrange(desc(pi_dollars))    dollars_per_pi |>   head(10) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 3,                caption = 'R01 grant dollars associated with specific PIs',                col.names=c('PI ID', 'Dollars (millions)'))

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: order measure “return” money NIH invests research enterprise, can measure scholarly output (.e., publications) per dollar invested. identify th highest performing grants outside R01 category. Much made wasteful spending outside investigator-initiated research. identify cost publications grants R01’s cost 1 million dollars. Productivity (publications / dollar) non-R01 grants can also identify specific publications associated grants least expensive publications. Publications productive grants can also identify productive PIs current R01s … can identify -time produtive PIs, independent grant type time frame … productive PIs time publications productive PIs time patents Jeremy Berg head Institute General Medical Sciences (NIGMS) 2003-2011, routinely provided analysis funding trends NIGMS “Feedback Loop” blog. One measured productivity per grant dollar measuring “scholarly output” (.e., publications) function direct costs. plot increase productivity per dollar, inflection point $700K, number publications drops, suggesting negative influence grant money scholarly output. interesting covered . flesh analysis look institutes perform measure (Berg, now Lorsch, analyzed GM). One caveat access total.cost NIH EXPORTER, numbers include indirect costs. , real cost tax-payer. First, need calculate lifetime costs R01 grants. Next, need identify grants bins Berg previously alluded . dplyr makes easy ntile() function. Berg previously divided grants ~15 bins, ’ll bin ~5%. looks better. Now can make summary plots … Productivity versus grant costs institute.
code: high_perf_not_r01 <- projects |>   filter(activity != 'R01') |>   left_join(project_io, by = 'project_num') |>   select(project_num, total_cost, n_pubs) |>   filter(total_cost > 1e6 & n_pubs > 0) |>   mutate(cost_per_pub = total_cost / n_pubs) |>   arrange(cost_per_pub)  high_perf_not_r01 |>   head(10) |>   mutate(total_cost = round(total_cost / 1e6, 3),          cost_per_pub = comma(round(cost_per_pub, 0))) |>   knitr::kable(caption='Productivity (publications / dollar) of non-R01 grants',                col.names=c('Project ID', 'Project cost (dollars, millions)',                            'Number of publications', 'Cost per publications (dollars)')) high_perf_not_r01 |>   head(1) |>   select(project_num) |>   left_join(publinks, by = 'project_num') |>   head(5) |>   knitr::kable(caption='Publications from the most productive grants',                col.names=c('Project ID', 'Pubmed ID')) productive_pis <- projects |>   filter(activity == 'R01') |>   select(project_num) |>   left_join(project_io, by = 'project_num') |>   left_join(project_pis, by = 'project_num') |>   group_by(pi_id) |>   summarize(total_pi_dollars = sum(total_cost, na.rm = TRUE),             total_pubs = sum(n_pubs)) |>   mutate(pub_cost = total_pi_dollars / total_pubs) |>   # prevent PI Ids from being commafied   mutate(pi_id = as.character(pi_id)) |>   arrange(pub_cost)  productive_pis |>   head(10) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 0,                format.args = list(big.mark = ','),                col.names = c('PI ID',                              'Cost per publication (dollars)',                              'Total publications',                              'Total project costs (dollars)')) productive_pis_all_time <- projects |>   select(project_num, activity) |>   left_join(project_io, by = 'project_num') |>   left_join(project_pis, by = 'project_num') |>   group_by(pi_id, activity) |>   summarize(total_pi_dollars = sum(total_cost, na.rm = TRUE),             total_pubs = sum(n_pubs),             total_patents = sum(n_patents)) |>   ungroup() |>   filter(total_pi_dollars >= 1e6) |>   mutate(pub_cost = total_pi_dollars / total_pubs,          patent_cost = total_pi_dollars / total_patents) |>   select(pi_id, activity, pub_cost, patent_cost,           total_pubs, total_patents, total_pi_dollars)  productive_pis_all_time |>   select(-patent_cost, -total_patents) |>   arrange(pub_cost) |>   head(10) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 0,                format.args = list(big.mark = ','),                caption = 'Most productive PIs all time for publications',                col.names = c('PI ID', 'Grant type',                              'Cost per publication (dollars)',                              'Total publications',                              'Total dollars')) productive_pis_all_time |>   select(-pub_cost, -total_pubs) |>   arrange(patent_cost) |>   head(10) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 0,                format.args = list(big.mark = ','),                caption = 'Most productive PIs all time for patents',                col.names = c('PI ID', 'Grant type',                              'Cost per patent (dollars)',                              'Total patents',                              'Total dollars')) # calculate costs of all grants, over the entire lifetime of the grant grant_costs <- projects |>   filter(institute %in% nih_institutes & activity == 'R01') |>   left_join(project_io, by = 'project_num') |>   select(institute, project_num, total_cost, n_pubs) |>   unique()  grant_costs #> # A tibble: 116,579 × 4 #>    institute project_num total_cost n_pubs #>    <fct>     <chr>            <dbl>  <int> #>  1 AA        R01AA000187     192057     67 #>  2 AA        R01AA000279    1368179      6 #>  3 AA        R01AA000626    4256757    118 #>  4 AA        R01AA002666    2635998    171 #>  5 AA        R01AA002686    9560051     73 #>  6 AA        R01AA003037     710028     16 #>  7 AA        R01AA003490    2285856     33 #>  8 AA        R01AA003972    2695918     58 #>  9 AA        R01AA004610    5035947     39 #> 10 AA        R01AA004961     477993     76 #> # ℹ 116,569 more rows bin_grant_costs <- grant_costs |>   group_by(institute) |>   group_by(n_tile = ntile(total_cost, 20))   bin_grant_costs #> # A tibble: 116,579 × 5 #> # Groups:   n_tile [20] #>    institute project_num total_cost n_pubs n_tile #>    <fct>     <chr>            <dbl>  <int>  <int> #>  1 AA        R01AA000187     192057     67      1 #>  2 AA        R01AA000279    1368179      6      8 #>  3 AA        R01AA000626    4256757    118     19 #>  4 AA        R01AA002666    2635998    171     16 #>  5 AA        R01AA002686    9560051     73     20 #>  6 AA        R01AA003037     710028     16      3 #>  7 AA        R01AA003490    2285856     33     15 #>  8 AA        R01AA003972    2695918     58     16 #>  9 AA        R01AA004610    5035947     39     20 #> 10 AA        R01AA004961     477993     76      2 #> # ℹ 116,569 more rows # Berg's original values ... # breaks <- c(175000, 200000, 225000, 250000, 300000, 375000, 400000, #           450000, 500000, 600000, 700000, 800000, 900000, 1000000) min.lifetime.cost <- round(min(grant_costs$total_cost, na.rm = TRUE), -4) # round to 10,000s max.lifetime.cost <- round(max(grant_costs$total_cost, na.rm = TRUE), -5)  # step is average size of an award step <- 1e6  breaks <- seq(min.lifetime.cost, max.lifetime.cost, step) breaks #>   [1] 0.00e+00 1.00e+06 2.00e+06 3.00e+06 4.00e+06 5.00e+06 6.00e+06 #>   [8] 7.00e+06 8.00e+06 9.00e+06 1.00e+07 1.10e+07 1.20e+07 1.30e+07 #>  [15] 1.40e+07 1.50e+07 1.60e+07 1.70e+07 1.80e+07 1.90e+07 2.00e+07 #>  [22] 2.10e+07 2.20e+07 2.30e+07 2.40e+07 2.50e+07 2.60e+07 2.70e+07 #>  [29] 2.80e+07 2.90e+07 3.00e+07 3.10e+07 3.20e+07 3.30e+07 3.40e+07 #>  [36] 3.50e+07 3.60e+07 3.70e+07 3.80e+07 3.90e+07 4.00e+07 4.10e+07 #>  [43] 4.20e+07 4.30e+07 4.40e+07 4.50e+07 4.60e+07 4.70e+07 4.80e+07 #>  [50] 4.90e+07 5.00e+07 5.10e+07 5.20e+07 5.30e+07 5.40e+07 5.50e+07 #>  [57] 5.60e+07 5.70e+07 5.80e+07 5.90e+07 6.00e+07 6.10e+07 6.20e+07 #>  [64] 6.30e+07 6.40e+07 6.50e+07 6.60e+07 6.70e+07 6.80e+07 6.90e+07 #>  [71] 7.00e+07 7.10e+07 7.20e+07 7.30e+07 7.40e+07 7.50e+07 7.60e+07 #>  [78] 7.70e+07 7.80e+07 7.90e+07 8.00e+07 8.10e+07 8.20e+07 8.30e+07 #>  [85] 8.40e+07 8.50e+07 8.60e+07 8.70e+07 8.80e+07 8.90e+07 9.00e+07 #>  [92] 9.10e+07 9.20e+07 9.30e+07 9.40e+07 9.50e+07 9.60e+07 9.70e+07 #>  [99] 9.80e+07 9.90e+07 1.00e+08 1.01e+08 1.02e+08 1.03e+08 1.04e+08 #> [106] 1.05e+08 1.06e+08 1.07e+08 1.08e+08 1.09e+08 1.10e+08 1.11e+08 #> [113] 1.12e+08 1.13e+08 1.14e+08 1.15e+08  dollar_bin_grant_costs <- grant_costs |>   group_by(institute) |>   mutate(dollar.tile = findInterval(total_cost, vec = breaks,                                      all.inside = TRUE, rightmost.closed = TRUE))  dollar_bin_grant_costs #> # A tibble: 116,579 × 5 #> # Groups:   institute [25] #>    institute project_num total_cost n_pubs dollar.tile #>    <fct>     <chr>            <dbl>  <int>       <int> #>  1 AA        R01AA000187     192057     67           1 #>  2 AA        R01AA000279    1368179      6           2 #>  3 AA        R01AA000626    4256757    118           5 #>  4 AA        R01AA002666    2635998    171           3 #>  5 AA        R01AA002686    9560051     73          10 #>  6 AA        R01AA003037     710028     16           1 #>  7 AA        R01AA003490    2285856     33           3 #>  8 AA        R01AA003972    2695918     58           3 #>  9 AA        R01AA004610    5035947     39           6 #> 10 AA        R01AA004961     477993     76           1 #> # ℹ 116,569 more rows  dollar_bin_grant_costs |> group_by(dollar.tile) |> summarize(count = n()) #> # A tibble: 44 × 2 #>    dollar.tile count #>          <int> <int> #>  1           1 25143 #>  2           2 50436 #>  3           3 21171 #>  4           4 10444 #>  5           5  4061 #>  6           6  2297 #>  7           7  1290 #>  8           8   659 #>  9           9   357 #> 10          10   232 #> # ℹ 34 more rows dollar_bin_grant_costs |>   # need to remove higher tiles because there are too few grants   filter(dollar.tile <= 13) |>   ggplot(aes(x = factor(dollar.tile), y = n_pubs)) +   geom_boxplot(outlier.shape = NA) +   scale_x_discrete(labels = breaks / 1e6) +    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=45, vjust=0.8)) +    scale_y_log10() +   theme_bw() +   facet_wrap(~ institute, scales = "free_x") +   ylab('Number of publications') +   xlab('Total costs (minimum, in millions)')

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: NIH provides funds differet grant programs: research: investigator-intitiated, actvities begin R (e.g., R01) program: activities begin P (e.g. P01) cooperative agreements: actvities begin U (e.g. U54) can examine total costs spent specific grants specific institutes time. Funds specific types grants GM, CA AI institutes can see institutes allocate money generally different types grants. Comparison research, program coop costs time
code: # from http://grants.nih.gov/grants/funding/funding_program.htm research_projects <- projects |> filter(grepl('^R', activity)) |> select(project_num) program_projects <- projects |> filter(grepl('^P', activity)) |> select(project_num) coop_projects <- projects |> filter(grepl('^U', activity)) |> select(project_num)  select_inst <- c('AI','CA','GM','HG','AA','MH')                  grant_costs <- projects |>   filter(institute %in% nih_institutes) |>   select(project_num, institute, fiscal_year, fy_cost)  research_costs <- grant_costs |>   semi_join(research_projects, by = 'project_num') |>   group_by(project_num, institute, fiscal_year) |>   summarize(project_cost = sum(fy_cost, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(type = 'research')  program_costs <- grant_costs |>   semi_join(program_projects, by = 'project_num') |>   group_by(project_num, institute, fiscal_year) |>   summarize(project_cost = sum(fy_cost, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(type = 'program')  coop_costs <- grant_costs |>   semi_join(coop_projects, by = 'project_num') |>   group_by(project_num, institute, fiscal_year) |>   summarize(project_cost = sum(fy_cost, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   mutate(type = 'cooperative agreements')  combined_tbl <- bind_rows(research_costs, program_costs, coop_costs)  ggplot(combined_tbl, aes(x = factor(fiscal_year),                          y = project_cost,                          fill = type)) +   geom_boxplot(outlier.shape = NA) +    scale_y_log10(limits = c(1e4,1e7),                 labels = trans_format("log10", math_format(10^.x))) +   facet_wrap(~institute) +   theme_bw() +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +    theme(legend.position = 'bottom') +   xlab('') +   ylab('Total grant costs, log-scaled') +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: nihexporter exposes project.start project.end, can use examine duration projects. example, can identify longest running R01 grants.
code: long_grants <- projects |>   filter(activity == 'R01') |>   select(project_num, project_start, project_end) |>   group_by(project_num) |>   # use lubridate here   summarize(longest_run = max(project_end) - min(project_start)) |>   arrange(desc(longest_run)) |>   mutate(in_years = as.numeric(longest_run) / 365) |>   select(project_num, in_years)  long_grants |>   head(10) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 2,                caption = 'Longest running R01 grants (all-time)',                col.names=c('Project ID', 'Duration (years)'))

title: Introduction to nihexporter
text: Geographical distribution grant dollar easily visualized using package.
code: state.data <- data.frame(org.state = state.abb,                          state.name = tolower(state.name))  state_funding <- projects |>   select(application.id) |>   left_join(project_orgs) |>   left_join(org_info) |>   left_join(projects, by = 'application.id') |>   select(application.id, org.state, fy.cost) |>   group_by(org.state) |>   summarize(total.fy.cost = sum(fy.cost) / 1e9)  cost.by.state <- state_funding |>   left_join(state.data) |>   select(state.name, total.fy.cost) |>   filter(state.name != "NA") |>   mutate(region=state.name, cost = total.fy.cost) |>   select(region, cost) |>   data.frame()  state.map.data <- map_data("state")  plot_data <- left_join(state.map.data, cost.by.state)  ggplot() +    geom_polygon(data=plot_data,                        aes(x=long, y=lat, group = group, fill=plot_data$cost),                       colour="black") +   scale_fill_continuous(low = "lightgrey", high = "red", guide="colorbar") +   theme_bw() +   labs(fill = "Total Cost per year \n (Billions of dollars)",x="", y="") +        #title = "Total cost per fiscal year by state"    scale_y_continuous(breaks=c()) +   scale_x_continuous(breaks=c()) +   theme(panel.border =  element_blank()) +   coord_fixed(ratio = 1.4)

text: Hesselberth et. al. (2015). nihexporter: R package NIH funding data bioRxiv URL http://biorxiv.org/content/early/2015/12/02/033456
code: @Article{,   title = {nihexporter: an R package for NIH funding data},   journal = {bioRxiv},   year = {2015},   author = {Jay Hesselberth and Erin Baschal and Nick Ellinwood and Ashley Pacheco and Sally Peach and Mary Sweet and Yuying Wang},   url = {http://biorxiv.org/content/early/2015/12/02/033456}, }

title: NIH funding from 1985-2021
text: nihexporter R package provides minimal set data NIH EXPORTER database, contains information NIH biomedical research funding 1985-2021. keep package lightweight, many details omitted can easily retrieved NIH RePORTER.

title: NIH funding from 1985-2021
text: Install package github : Note: large data package (>40 Mb)
code: # install.packages('pak') pak::pkg_install("jayhesselberth/nihexporter")

title: NIH funding from 1985-2021
text: projects: provides data funded projects NIH. project_pis: links project numbers (project.num) principal investigator IDs (pi.id). project_orgs: links DUNS numbers (org.duns) projects table information specific organizations . publinks: links Pubmed IDs (pmid) project numbers (project.num). publications: provides information individual publications, including Relative Citation Ratio values (rcr). patents: links project IDs (project.num) patent.id. clinical_studies: links project IDs associated clinical trials. project_io: pre-computed n.pubs, n.patents project.cost project.num. Note: Abstracts NIH EXPORTER provided significantly increase size package.

title: NIH funding from 1985-2021

title: Retrieve Relative Citation Ratio (RCR) for PubMed IDs. — rcr
text: pmids vector PubMed IDs retrieve (max 1000 time)

title: Retrieve Relative Citation Ratio (RCR) for PubMed IDs. — rcr
text: tibble including following variables: pmid PubMed ID authors publication authors citation_count total citations citations_per_year mean citations per year expected_citations_per_year estimated field_citation_rate rate relative field is_research_article boolean journal journal name abbr. nih_percentile percentile relative_citation_ratio RCR title article title year publication year See URL full details.

title: Retrieve Relative Citation Ratio (RCR) for PubMed IDs. — rcr
code: pmids <- c(26001965, 25015380) rcr(pmids) #> # A tibble: 2 × 25 #>       pmid  year title                 authors journal is_research_article #>      <int> <int> <chr>                 <chr>   <chr>   <chr>               #> 1 25015380  2014 High resolution mapp… D Suzi… Genome… Yes                 #> 2 26001965  2015 Global analysis of R… Sally … Nuclei… Yes                 #> # ℹ 19 more variables: relative_citation_ratio <dbl>, #> #   nih_percentile <dbl>, human <dbl>, animal <dbl>, #> #   molecular_cellular <dbl>, apt <dbl>, is_clinical <chr>, #> #   citation_count <int>, citations_per_year <dbl>, #> #   expected_citations_per_year <dbl>, field_citation_rate <dbl>, #> #   provisional <chr>, x_coord <dbl>, y_coord <dbl>, cited_by_clin <lgl>, #> #   cited_by <list>, references <list>, doi <chr>, last_modified <chr>

title: nihexporter 0.9
text: Reload projects data. fy.cost now spans 1985-2021. columns projects table updated date types Recalculate project_io table. New clinical_studies table. Removed project_orgs org_info tables, now main projects table. rcr values added publications table, added new rcr() function enables retrieval RCR values specific PMIDs. remove duplicate rows NAs project_pis table.

title: nihexporter 0.9
text: Added pkgdown documentation removed unused columns (journal.title.abbr publications) tables minimize package size. Refactored data loading scripts
